title: 115_hr6989
content: Restricting federal assistance benefits to verified citizens. Restriction on Federal assistance benefits eligibility based on citizenship requirement. Federal assistance benefit defined as aid provided under any Federal program. Citizenship, attestation, and verification requirements outlined. Citizenship, attestation, and verification requirements must be met for eligibility for Federal assistance benefits. Attestation involves declaring citizenship in writing, while verification ensures citizenship status. An individual meets the citizenship verification requirement for Federal assistance benefits by providing satisfactory documentary evidence of citizenship or nationality, a photographic identity document, and their name during the application process. The individual must provide documentary evidence, a photographic identity document, name, and social security account number to confirm citizenship or nationality status for Federal assistance benefits. The individual must provide name, social security account number, and identity information for confirmation of citizenship or nationality status for Federal assistance benefits. An entity must submit this information to the Commissioner of Social Security for confirmation. Upon receipt, the Commissioner compares the submitted information with records to confirm or deny. The entity submits name, social security number, and identity information to the Commissioner of Social Security for confirmation of citizenship. The Commissioner then transmits the information to the Secretary of Homeland Security for further confirmation. Upon receiving information from an entity, the Secretary of Homeland Security confirms whether an individual is a US citizen or national. Entities must verify individuals through the SAVE Program to ensure they are not listed as noncitizens. The SAVE Program verifies individuals to confirm US citizenship. If no documentary evidence is provided or confirmation is not received, the entity must notify the individual of ineligibility for Federal assistance benefits and provide an appeals process. The Federal benefit program allows individuals to appeal determinations of ineligibility for assistance benefits. Children or family members can meet citizenship requirements for benefits if a parent or guardian meets the requirement. The citizenship requirement for Federal benefit programs can be met by a household member, except for specific programs where the elderly or disabled individual must meet the requirement within their household. Once an individual meets the citizenship requirement for a Federal assistance benefit, they will continue to meet the requirement as long as they remain eligible. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may issue regulations and guidance for the administration of this section, including specifying the declaration form and verification process for citizenship. The provisions of this section supersede any provisions of law relating to the eligibility for Federal assistance benefits of individuals based on citizenship, nationality, or immigration status, unless the Director of the Office of Management and Budget may issue regulations and guidance for the administration of this section. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget can disqualify entities from providing Federal assistance benefits if they repeatedly give benefits to individuals who do not meet citizenship requirements or fail to submit required information. The entity will be added to the List of Excluded Individuals/Entities until the benefits are recovered. Inspectors general monitor programs for compliance. The Inspector General for the respective Federal Department or agency monitors compliance of entities providing benefits under Federal assistance programs based on income or resources of the beneficiary. The definition of a Federal assistance program includes provisions of Federal law authorizing benefits and the Social Security Act. Subsection (a) applies to eligibility determinations made one year after the effective date. The enactment of this Act establishes a transition rule where individuals must meet citizenship requirements within 2 years to remain eligible for Federal assistance benefits.
